Carol Pineau is the writer, director and producer of ""Africa: Open for Business"" and a contributor to CNN.
She's covered Africa for over 10 years.
When I spoke with her from the shores of the Mediterranean, Pineau was still shocked her documentary was screened in front of the international audiences.
That's why I'm so amazed to be here, because it really isn't about documentaries, particularly serious documentaries like this.

Well, it sounds like a lot of fun.
Tell us about your documentary.
You're profiling all of these African businessmen and women.
How did you get this idea?
What I really wanted to do was show a different Africa, and business is the root to showing that.
We are taught in America, I think, from the time we are young, that Africa receives and we give.
When a child doesn't finish their plate of food, `There's starving children in Ethiopia.
You better finish your food.
We're constantly taught that Africa is a victim.
And I wanted to show a strong Africa.
I wanted to show the Africa that I knew was there but never got a chance to report on, because no one really asks for those kinds of reports.
I wanted to show the Africa that has high-rises and stock markets and cell phones and Internet cafes--and really an Africa that is not that different from America in certain places.
Tell me about one person that you profiled that you really thought was extraordinary.
One that was really extraordinary was the man that started the cell phone company in Congo, Alieu Conteh.
Now Congo was in full-scale war when he started this.
People think that you have to have good governance.
What I really wanted to show was, yes, good governance makes it easy, but even in the worst of situations there is a human drive to build a better future for your children.
And that's exactly what Alieu did.
He came into Congo as the rebels were coming into the airport of Kinshasa.
He had his manager design a cell tower.
The locals got together and collected scrap metal, soldered it all together, and he built a tower.
And then the locals were so invested in the tower they protected that tower from both the rebels and government soldiers.

Africa offers the highest return on direct investment in the world.
There is nowhere that you can get as much money back from your investment as in Africa.
And yet at the same time Africa attracts the least amount of foreign direct investment.
So you have to ask why.

We're not even there to discussing the risk factor.
Right now, when you mention investment in Africa, the door is just shut.
People just don't see Africa as a place to do business.

I think that as we can start getting some of these images out there, you know, an Africa that is not just refugee camps and animal parks but an Africa that's a lot more complex, as it really is on the ground, that investors will start seeing Africa in that way.

And the unfortunate thing about films like this is that nobody in the media is funding anything like this.

If there is any coverage of Africa, it's of the wars and disasters, which is very important to cover, but to exclusively cover that really just feeds into the stereotype that all of Africa is just coast-to-coast war and disaster.

2013 may have been, as some gay and lesbian activists put it, the gayest year ever.

The Defense of Marriage Act was struck down by the Supreme Court, 18 states now extend marriage rights to same sex couples, the number of states now offering those rights more than doubled in just one year.
But as we begin 2014, there's another issue gaining traction - transgender rights.
Ross Murray is the director of news at an organization of gay and lesbian activists called GLAAD.
He joins us from our New York bureau.
Thank you very much for doing this, Ross.
Thank you for having me here.
Now, are transgendered issues something that registered all for most Americans?
It registers a lot less.
I think that the support for marriage equality has been following the recognition that people know someone who is gay and lesbian.
And once they feel like they know and have a relationship with someone, then they understand that folks need protections and responsibilities just like everyone else.
And the transgender visibility has not been as high.
I think as the familiarity is going to increase then some of those same protections are going to follow.
Now, 2014 is starting off with a new transgender rights law in California.
Can you tell us about that?
Sure.
It's called the School Success and Opportunity Act.
It went into effect on January 1st.
And this is the law that provides basic protections for transgender students at school.
It allows them to use the facilities consistent with their gender identity, allowing them to play on sports teams, adding protections against bullying and harassment.
What about other states?
Are you looking at anything else that's going on?
There's a lot of work this year, and I think something we're going to see in 2014 is a greater push for transgender-inclusive health care.

Connecticut just became the fifth state to require transgender medical coverage, sending a directive to health insurance companies that operate within the state that they should include benefits for transgender and transgender-specific care.
So, is the issue that sex reassignment is not included?
Transgender people are denied health care both for transition services, things like hormones, things like that.
And sometimes, even within private insurance, the services that are covered are gender-specific.

And so, if someone, say, is born a man, suddenly they're excluded from receiving mammograms or issues for breast cancer, and those are things that need to get fixed in terms to create consistent health care for transgender people.
There was a certain amount of publicity for transgender people in 2013.
There is the Netflix TV series ""Orange is the New Black,"" which has a transgender character who was named one of the most influential people of 2013.
Do you think that has the potential to change anything?
I think so.
One, I think that having that visibility and a fictional story that tells the story of a complex person.

Most of the time in the media, on the news side of things, transgender people are often just the victims of violence and they're not talked about until after they have been attacked and perhaps murdered, which it happened a lot also in 2013.
In a character like Laverne Cox's character in ""Orange is the New Black,"" helped to provide a much richer character that people could actually relate to.

One of the things we've talking about on the news side of GLAAD is that we shouldn't just be hearing about transgender people after they're the victims of violence; we need to be hearing about their lives when they're living - what they go through, what their accomplishments are.
